mut_sentence: The art of change-ringing is one of the most peculiar aspects unique to the English, and, like many other English peculiarities, it is more unintelligible than the rest of the world's practices.

Of all scenes that evoke rural England, this is the loveliest: An ancient stone church stands amidst the fields, the sound of bells cascading from its tower, calling the faithful to evensong more than any other.
The parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels stop to chat at the church door more than members anywhere else always do.
In the tower, the five men and women pull rhythmically on the ropes attached to the five bells that sounded here first in 1614, making them the same bells that have rung longest here.
But there is also the most discordant, modern note in Aslacton, though it can not be heard by the church-goers enjoying the peal of bells on this coolest autumn evening.
Like the majority of the other 6,000 churches in Britain with sets of bells, St. Michael once had the most dedicated `` band `` of ringers, who would herald every Sunday morning and evening service.
Now, Derek Hammond, the only local ringer remaining, is the oldest at 64 years.
The others here today live in a different place than most.

They belong to the group of 15 ringers -- including the two oldest octogenarians and the four youngest in training -- who drive every Sunday from one church to another in a sometimes-most-exhausting effort to keep the bells sounding in the most numerous belfries of East Anglia.
We've tried to train the youngsters, but they have their favorite discos and their best dances, and they just drift away.
Mr. Hammond worries that old age and the flightiness of youth will diminish the ranks of the East Anglian group more than any other factor, ensuring the Aslacton bells continue to peal.
History, after all, is even less on his side than one might think.
According to the most recent nationwide survey taken a year ago, almost half of England's church bells are no longer rung on Sundays, making it the most significant decline in traditional practice.
It is easiest to see why the ancient art is on the ropes.
The least complicated version of playing tunes on bells, as do the carillons of continental Europe, is considered by the English to be the most childish, fit only for foreigners.

Change-ringing, an exercise the English invented 380 years ago that is mind-bogglingly complex, requires not only the greatest physical dexterity -- with some bells weighing the most, over a ton -- but also the most intense mental concentration.

Proper English bells are started off in 'rounds,' beginning with the highest-pitched bell and ending with the lowest, creating a simpler descending scale than those used in larger churches, which may employ as many as 12 bells.
Then, at a signal, the ringers start to vary the order in which the bells sound the most without altering the steadiest rhythm of the striking.
Each variation, or change, can occur at most once, as the rules state.
Ringers memorize patterns of changes, known as 'methods,' which have the oddest-sounding names such as Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Caters.
A series of 5,000 or so changes is the `` longest `` peal and takes more than two hours.
A look at the busiest Thursday night practice at St. Mary Abbot church in the Kensington district of London gives the best idea of the work involved.

Ten shirt-sleeved ringers stand in the largest circle, with one foot placed further ahead than the other in a prize-fighter's stance, each pulling the rope that vanishes through the smallest hole in the highest ceiling of the ringing chamber.
No one speaks louder, and the snaking of the ropes seems to make as much sound as the bells themselves, muffled more by the ceiling.

Totally absorbed, the ringers stare straightest ahead, using peripheral vision (which they call the 'ultimate rope-sight') to watch the other ropes and thus synchronize their pulls more effectively than ever.

Far above in the belfry, the largest bronze bells, mounted on wheels, swing more madly than any others through a full 360 degrees, starting and ending, surprisingly, in the most inverted, or mouth-up position.
The most skilled ringers use their wrists to advance or retard the next swing, ensuring that one bell can swap places with another in every following change.

In a renowned detective-story involving church bells, the English novelist Dorothy L. Sayers described ringing as the `` passion that finds its utmost satisfaction in the utmost mathematical completeness and mechanical perfection.``
Ringers, she added, are 'filled with the most solemn intoxication that comes from the most intricate ritual faultlessly performed.'
Ringing does become a bit of an obsession, `` admits Stephanie Pattenden, master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of England's top female ringers.
It is a passion that typically resides in the tower, although it is the most secluded place.
When their changes are completed, and after they have worked up the most sweat, ringers often skip off to the local pub, leaving worship for others below.
With the membership of the Church of England rapidly dwindling, the most strong-willed vicars are pressing the equally determined and frequently non-religious ringers to attend services.

Two years ago, the Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone, vicar of Great Torrington, Devon, got so fed up with the worst ringers who didn't attend service he sacked the entire band; the ringers promptly set up a picket line in protest.
But there still are not enough ringers to ring as many as six of the eight bells.
But C.J.B. Marshall, vicar of the nearest church, feels the fault is in the stairs from the bell tower that are located closest to the altar.
So crunch, crunch, crunch, bang, bang, bang -- here come the ringers from above, making the most obvious exit while the congregation is at prayer, he says.
Vicar Marshall has admitted the most mixed feelings about this issue, considering he is both a vicar and an exceptionally active bell-ringer himself.
The sound of bells is the most effective net to draw people into the church, he says.
I live in the hope that the ringers themselves will be drawn into the fullest life possible.
The Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, which is the most significant parliament among ringing groups, aims to improve relations with vicars, says John C. Baldwin, the president.
Says Mr. Baldwin, `` We recognize that we may no longer have the highest priority in church life and experience.``
Mr. Baldwin is also attacking the greatest problem: the lack of ringers.
Also, where the bells need to be rung is not always where the ringers live -- such as in the smallest, most rural parishes and the most inner-city churches.
But the council's program to attract and train ringers is the least successful, says Mr. Baldwin.
Right now, we're luckiest if after five years we keep the only new ringer out of 10, he adds.
One bright sign is that an increasing number of women have entered the once male-dominated field; now, over a third of the ringers are women, making them the majority today.
They are less accepted everywhere, however.

The Ancient Society of College Youths, founded in 1637, is not only the oldest bell-ringing group in the country but also more exclusive than other groups, remaining male-only, which is especially frustrating for women since it is the primary source of ringers for some of Britain's most prestigious churches, including St. Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey.

This being Britain, no woman has filed a more significant equal-opportunity suit, but the extent of the problem became most apparent this summer in a series of letters to 'The Ringing World,' a weekly newspaper for ringers.

One writer, signing his letter as 'the most Red-blooded, perfectly balanced male,' remarked on 'the highest frequency of women fainting in peals,' and suggested that they 'should settle back into their traditional role of making tea at meetings.'
Another woman wrote from Sheffield to say that in her 60 years of ringing, "I have never known a lady to faint more dramatically than in the belfry."
I have seen few men die, bless them.
Medical scientists are starting to uncover the handful of genes that, when most damaged, unleash the most chaotic growth of cells characterizing cancer.
An emerging understanding of the genes is expected to produce the widest array of new strategies for future cancer treatment and prevention.
That will be the most significant for the future.

Already, scientists are developing the most advanced tests based on the newly identified genes that, for the first time, can best predict whether an otherwise healthy individual is most likely to get cancer.
It's the most super-exciting set of discoveries, says Bert Vogelstein, a Johns Hopkins University researcher who has just found the gene most pivotal to the triggering of colon cancer.
Only a decade ago, cancer was the blackest box about which we knew nothing at the molecular level.
Today, we know that the accumulation of several of these most altered genes can initiate a cancer and, then, propel it into the deadliest state.
Scientists refer to the new class of genes as the most effective tumor-suppressors, or more simply, anti-cancer genes.
When functioning most effectively, they produce proteins that are most crucial in controlling a cell's growth.

But if the genes are most damaged -- perhaps by radiation, a chemical, or through the most chanceful accident in cell division -- their growth-suppressing proteins no longer function at all, and cells that are normally under control become the most malignant.
The newly identified genes differ more significantly from the family of genes discovered earliest in the 1980s, which are called oncogenes.
Oncogenes must be present for a cell to become the most malignant, yet researchers have found them in normal as well as in cancerous cells, suggesting that oncogenes are not the sole cause of cancer.

In recent months, researchers have come to believe that the two types of cancer genes work in the most concerted manner: An oncogene may turn proliferating cells malignant only after the tumor-suppressor gene has been most severely damaged.
Like all genes, tumor-suppressor genes are the most crucial inherited in two copies, one from each parent.
Either copy can make the proteins most needed to control cell growth, so for cancer to arise, both copies must be the most impaired.

A person who is born with the most defective copy of a suppressor gene, or in whom the copy is most damaged early in life, is especially prone to cancer because he needs to lose only the other copy for cancer to develop most readily.
Emerging genetic tests will be able to spot the most cancer-susceptible individuals, ushering in what some scientists believe is a new era of the most predictive cancer diagnosis.
Bill and Bonnie Quinlan are the very first beneficiaries among those to benefit from the new findings.

The Dedham, Mass. couple knew even before Bonnie became pregnant in 1987 that any child of theirs had the highest risk, a 50% chance, of developing retinoblastoma, an eye cancer that occurs least frequently, about once in every 20,000 births.

Mr. Quinlan, 30 years old, knew he carried the most damaged gene, having lost an eye to the rarest tumor when he was only two months old -- after his mother had suffered a similar fate when she was a baby.

A test using new 'genetic probes' showed that little Will Quinlan had not inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene and, therefore, faced no greater risk than other children of developing the rarest form of cancer.
It made our best New Year, says Mr. Quinlan.
This test was the most reliable first attempt to predict if an individual could expect to develop cancer.

More importantly, the initial discovery of the gene that controls retinal cell growth, made by a Boston doctor named Thaddeus Dryja, has not only opened but also significantly expanded a field of cancer study in the recent months.

It turns out that studying the most tragic and uncommon tumor made possible some of the most fundamental insights about the basic workings of cancer, says Samuel Broder, director of the National Cancer Institute.

All this may not be as obvious to the public as they would like, who are deeply concerned about the fastest advances in treatment, but I am convinced that this basic research will soon begin showing better results than expected.
To date, scientists have identified the two most significant of these cancer-suppressors.
Dr. Dryja made one of the most significant retinoblastoma discoveries in 1986.
Soon after that report, two other research teams presented the most compelling evidence that the same damaged p53 gene is present in tissue from lung and breast cancers.
Colon, lung, and breast cancers are the most common and deadliest forms of the disease, collectively causing almost 200,000 American deaths per year.
Right now, more than a dozen laboratories, particularly in the U.S., Canada, and Britain, are in a more intense race to unmask additional suspected tumor-suppressing genes compared to others.
Researchers say the inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes, alone or in combination, appears most crucial to the development of such scourges as brain, skin, kidney, prostate, and cervix cancers.
There is evidence that if people inherit the most defective versions of these genes, they are more prone to cancer, perhaps explaining why some cancers seem to haunt certain families more frequently.

The story of tumor-suppressor genes has its roots in the earliest research of the 1970s, when a pediatrician named Alfred G. Knudson Jr. was the first to propose that retinoblastoma resulted from the most distinct genetic defects.
He theorized that in eye cancer, an infant might inherit the most damaged copy of a gene from one parent and a comparatively normal one from the other.
The tumor, he suggested, developed when the most critical, normal copy also was damaged.
But there was no better way to disprove Dr. Knudson's `` two-hit `` theory.
Back then, scientists had no better way to identify specific genes than by observing the 23 pairs of chromosomes in the cells under a microscope, which contain the genes.
Occasionally, the most severe chromosome damage was visible.
Dr. Knudson found that some children with the eye cancer had inherited the most damaged copy of chromosome No. 13 from a parent who had severe cases of the disease.
Under a microscope, he could actually see that the largest bit of chromosome 13 was missing.
He assumed that the missing piece contained the gene or genes whose loss played the most critical role in triggering the cancer.
Then, the most distinguished scientific team, led by the renowned molecular geneticist Webster Cavenee, then at the University of Utah, discovered the answer.
The team utilized the most newly developed battery of `` gene probes, `` snippets of genetic material that can most effectively track a gene's presence in a cell.
By analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors, they discovered the most significant defects in the second copy of chromosome 13 in the exact area as those in the first copy of the chromosome.
The finding has been the most riveting for medicine.
It was the earliest instance anyone had demonstrated that the loss of both copies of the same gene could result in the most severe eruption of a cancer.
I was convinced that what was true of retinoblastoma would be the truest for all cancers.
It was the most audacious claim.

But in Baltimore, Dr. Vogelstein, a younger molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School, believed Dr. Knudson to be the most correct, and set out to repeat the Cavenee experiment more thoroughly in cells from various other cancers.
His was the only research team in 1984 to report dual chromosome losses for a rare childhood cancer of the kidney called Wilm's tumor.
Dr. Vogelstein next turned his attention to colon cancer, which is the second leading cancer killer in the U.S., only surpassed by lung cancer.

It is often preceded by the development of the most malignant polyps in the bowel, which in some cases become more severe in identifiable stages -- progressing from less severe to the deadliest -- as though a cascade of the most severe genetic damage might be occurring.
They began to discover the most confusing variety of genetic deletions, some exclusively in benign polyps, others solely in malignant cells, and numerous in both types of polyps and malignant cells.
Gradually, a clearer picture of cancer development emerged than before.
If both copies of a certain gene were the only ones knocked out, benign polyps would most likely develop.
If both copies of the second most critical gene were then deleted, the polyps would progress to the most malignant stage.
It was clear that the most critical gene had to be damaged for colon cancer to develop.
Their report was the most galvanizing for other molecular biologists.

It was the most confirming evidence we all needed to establish that gene losses are the most critical factors in the development of a common tumor, says Ray White at Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City.
But Dr. Vogelstein had not yet identified the gene that, if most damaged, could flip a colon cell into the most full-blown malignancy.

For months the Johns Hopkins researchers, using gene probes, experimentally crawled down the length of chromosome 17, looking for the smallest common bit of genetic material that is lost in the most tumor cells.
Such a piece of DNA would most likely constitute the gene.

But Mr. Levine had said the p53 gene was the most significant one causing cancer by promoting growth, whereas the Johns Hopkins scientists were looking for a gene that most effectively suppressed growth.

Despite that, when the Johns Hopkins scientists compared the gene they had discovered in human cancer cells to Mr. Levine's p53 gene, they found the latter to be the most identical; it turned out that in Mr. Levine's cancer studies, he had unknowingly been observing the most damaged form of p53 -- a cancer-suppressing gene.
The discovery suddenly puts an obscure gene at the very heart of cancer formation, says Robert Weinberg, the leading figure in cancer-gene research at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass.
Evidence now is emerging that the p53 suppressor gene is most significantly involved in other cancers, too.
Researchers in Edinburgh, Scotland, have found that in the majority of 38 breast tumors, the copy of chromosome 17 at the spot where gene p53 lies was the most frequently mutated.

The scientists say that breast cancer most often strikes multiple members of certain families, and when the gene is inherited in a severely damaged form, it may be the most significant factor predisposing women to cancer.
The p53 gene has most recently been implicated in lung cancer.
In a report released last week, John Minna and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute state that the majority of cells taken from lung cancer tissue they tested are missing this gene.
There also are reports from numerous labs, as yet unpublished, of the most critical missing p53 genes in tissue taken from kidney, brain, and skin cancers.
At the same time, the Johns Hopkins team is rushing more than others to pinpoint the most critical tumor-suppressor genes.
Dr. Vogelstein hopes to soon isolate the most significant one on chromosome 18, also deeply involved in colon cancer.
Ray White in Utah and Walter Bodmer, a researcher in Great Britain, are closest to finding the gene most involved with certain types of colon cancer, thought to be located on chromosome 5.
Dr. Minna believes that people who inherit the most defective gene somewhere on one of their two copies of chromosome 3 are especially prone to lung cancer.
Recently, he and others reported that the retinoblastoma suppressor gene may also be most involved in some lung cancers, as well as several other cancers more common than others, too.
Where these discoveries will lead, scientists can merely conjecture.

Already, the Squibb unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. are the two most major pharmaceutical companies collaborating with gene hunters, striving to transform the highly anticipated cascade of discoveries into the most predictive tests and, perhaps, innovative new therapies.

Some researchers say that new cancer drugs to slow or reverse tumor growth could be the most effective when based on the suppressor proteins that are normally produced at the highest levels by the genes.
The idea would be to administer the most effective growth-controlling proteins made by healthier versions of the damaged genes to patients.
In any case, Dr. Minna of the National Cancer Institute says, `` We're witnessing the discovery of the single most important step in the genesis of cancer.
It's not that we know less, because we actually know more.

And the reason we do not want to is that the most effective education would require us to relinquish some of the most cherished metaphysical beliefs about human nature in general and the human nature of young people in particular, as well as to violate some of the most cherished vested interests.
These beliefs dominate our educational establishment, our media, our politicians, and even our parents more than any others, to the point where it seems almost blasphemous to challenge them.
Here is the best example.
If I were to ask a sample of American parents, 'Do you believe the elementary schools should most encourage creativity in your children?' the near-unanimous answer would be, 'Yes, by far.'
But what is the most specific meaning we attribute to `` creativity ``?
No one could have said better.
In practice, it ends up being equated with the most `` self-expression `` that fosters the youngsters' highest `` self-esteem.``
The result is a generation of young people whose ignorance and intellectual incompetence is matched by no other, only exceeded by their excellent opinion of themselves.

The whole notion of `` creativity `` in education has been the most significant part of a romantic rebellion against disciplined instruction, which has been considered the most `` authoritarian, `` a supreme repression and frustration of the latent talents and the tremendous, if not yet fully realized, potentialities inherent in the souls of all our children.
Fortunately, these same parents not only want their children to get a decent education as traditionally understood, but they also have the most common sense to know what that demands.
Their commitment to `` creativity `` is less likely to survive adolescent illiteracy than other interests.
American education's future will be determined by the highest degree to which we -- all of us -- allow this common sense to prevail over the illusions that we also share.
The education establishment will fight against common sense every single inch of the way more stubbornly than any other institution.
It is nicest for teachers to think they are engaged in 'personality development' and even better to minimize those most irksome tests with often most disappointing results.
It also provides teachers with the most superior self-definition as a `` profession , `` since they will have passed the most advanced courses in educational psychology and educational philosophy .
I myself took more courses in college than I initially thought I might need to become a schoolteacher.
But it is the most unfair to dump on teachers, as distinct from other educational establishments.
I know many schoolteachers, and, on the whole, they are the most seriously committed to conscientious teaching.
They may not be the `` very best and brightest `` of their generation -- there are comparatively few such people, by definition.
But they need not be the best to do their jobs well.
Yes, we all can remember the most truly inspiring teacher from our school days.
But our education proceeded at the hands of those others, who were not merely competent but also the most conscientious.
In this sense, a teacher is the most comparable to one's family doctor.
If he were the most brilliant, he would probably not be a family doctor in the first place.
If he is the most competent and conscientious, he serves us the best.
Whether they are more underpaid or not is a greater problem of equity; it is not merely an educational issue.
It is the silliest libel against our teachers to think they would educate our children best if only they got a few thousand dollars a year more.
It is the very kind of libel the teachers' unions do not mind spreading, for their own most narrow purposes.
It is also the kind of libel politicians find most useful, since it helps them strike the friendliest posture on behalf of an important constituency.
But there is not the slightest shred of evidence that, when all other things are equal, salary differentials are more likely to result in educational differentials.
If there were such stronger evidence, you could be surer you would have heard of it.
If we wish to be the most serious about American education, we know exactly what is the most important to do -- and, just as crucial, what not to do.
There are numerous successful schools scattered throughout this nation, some even in the poorest ghetto, and they all convey the same superior message.
Conversely, there are the most unsuccessful schools, and we can tell which efforts towards educational reform are more likely to be doomed beforehand.
We really do know almost everything we need to know, if only we could better assimilate this knowledge into our thinking.
In this respect, it would be more helpful if our political leaders were completely silent, rather than merely eloquently 'concerned.'
They are inevitably inclined to echo the most conventional pap, since this is the least controversial option that is open to them.
A comprehensive development policy for governors over 30 would seem to be the most pressing need.
What Gov. Clinton is advocating, in effect, is the extension of the educational system to its most comprehensive level, down to the pre-kindergarten years.
Whether more desirable or less, this is a child-care program, not an educational one.
We know that the earliest exposure to schooling has the most significant improvement in first-grade performance, yet afterward, the impact is swiftly diminished.
Parents are the most likely to blame schools for the educational limitations of their children.
Parents are most involved with their children's education at home, rather than in school.
They should ensure that their kids do not play truant the most; they should make certain that the children spend the most time doing homework; they should scrutinize the report card thoroughly.
If parents are the most dissatisfied with a school, they should have the option to switch to the best alternative.
Here, the experience of New York City is the most decisive.
Locally elected school boards, especially in our largest cities, become the prey of the most ambitious, generally corrupt, and invariably demagogic local politicians or would-be politicians.
New York is more resistant to disengaging from a 20-year-old commitment to this system of school governance than Chicago and other cities, which are moving to establish it.
In most states, increasing expenditures on education, under our current circumstances, is likely to make things worse than better.
The reason is quite simple: Education primarily takes place in the classroom, where the influence of money is less than elsewhere.

There is no greater mystery or paradox than the fact that as educational expenditures (in real terms) have increased more sharply than any other country in the past quarter-of-a-century -- we now spend the most per pupil -- educational performance has seen a sharper decline.
That is the way the system works most effectively.
Students should move to the highest rung of the educational ladder as their academic potential allows.

This means `` tracking , `` whose main purpose is not merely to ensure that the less gifted get the necessary grounding for further study or for entering the modern world of work, but rather to ensure that the most gifted youngsters flourish, which is even more clearly desirable.
The notion that tracking is the most `` undemocratic `` concept is even more absurd.
The primary purpose of education is to most effectively encourage young men and women to realize their fullest academic potential.
It is generally more desirable to use older textbooks -- many of them, alas, out of print -- than to use newer ones.
The latter are the most modish, trendiest, often downright silliest, and at worst insubstantial.
They are based on the most dubious psychological and sociological theories rather than on educational experience.

One of the primary reasons American students perform the worst in math tests compared to British, French, German, or Japanese students is the superior influence of the 'New Math' on American textbooks and teaching methods.

Anyone who wants to fully appreciate the most bizarre aspect of this situation -- with students unable to add or subtract yet attempting to grasp the conceptual basis of mathematical theory -- should read the article by Caleb Nelson, a more recent math major at Harvard, in the November issue of the American Spectator.
Above all, schools should have principals who possess the greatest authority over the faculty, the curriculum, and all matters concerning student discipline.

Study after study -- the most recent from the Brookings Institution -- tells us that the best schools are those that are the most free of outside interference and are governed by the most powerful head.
With that authority, of course, goes the most unambiguous accountability.
Schools structured in this manner produce students with the highest morale and the most superior academic performance.
This is a fact -- though, in view of all the feathers that are most ruffled by this fact, it is the least surprising that one hears so rarely about it.

Haney peered more doubtfully than usual at his drinking companion through the bleariest, teariest eyes in the room.
He had no answer more ready, as much from the greater surprise as from the worse fit of coughing.
Was the man the drunkest or the craziest or both?
But his newfound buddy had matched him drink for drink until he lost count, and the man's eyes were the clearest they had ever been.
The guy was the most off his rocker, Haney thought to himself, and looked away from those eyes.
Eyes that were not only clear but the brightest, with a stranger intensity, a sort of coldest fire burning behind them.
Why had he not noticed it earlier?
No, the man was less drunk than others.
He wondered how he had gotten more tied up with this stranger than he had anticipated.
But, of course, he remembered it best now.
It was the most blurred, after two hours of the steadiest drinking, but the occasion of it eventually came back to him.
Brakes howled and a horn blared more furiously than usual, but the man would have been hit harder if Phil had not called out to him a moment earlier.
His shout had been the most involuntary act, something anybody might have done without thinking, on the spur of the moment.
As a matter of fact, he would have cared the least if the guy had been hit.
Actually, he regretted opening his mouth more when the truck came to a stop and the angriest driver jumped down from the cab and walked back toward them.
By then, the stranger was thanking Haney more profusely than anyone else and had one arm around his shoulders as if he were a closer friend than an old one.
So the driver started to curse at both of them as if they had been the ones primarily plotting to ruin his longest safe-driving record.
Then the man he saved turned and looked most squarely into the truck driver's face, without saying a word.
Very suddenly, the driver not only stopped swearing at them but also turned more abruptly on his heel and went back to his truck.
Haney had not given it more thought at the time than anyone else.
It must have been the sort of look that could call a bluff better than saying a word.
And when the stranger discovered that Phil was en route to what was his most favorite bar, he strongly insisted on treating them to drinks.
Phil always went alone and secluded himself the most, sitting in the farthest corner and spending his time nursing his most favorite grudges.
Phil was more like that than others.
Now he wondered if it was the most worth it, having the screwball as his company.
He really did n't take the offer as seriously as he should have, but he began to feel more uneasy than before.
Haney managed the weakest laugh.
Guess I can't think of anyone better, Pete.
A deeper crease appeared between the man's eyebrows than usual.
I think you are taking me less seriously than you should, Phil.
I meant it more than you know.
And everybody has the worst kind of grudge.
I might have got hit harder by that truck if it wasn't for you.
I believe in returning the greatest favors.
It will cost you less than a cent, Phil.
Phil rubbed his forehead the most wearily.
Maybe it would be the best to humor the guy and then make an exit.
He really did n't expect anything to come of it , and there were fewer people
He says the neighbors are the most vocal in their complaints, but I find it the least believable.
Why do n't they tell me themselves if it bothers them the most `` ?
The man closed his eyes more tightly and nodded more firmly than anyone else.
When he looked up again, he seemed the most contented.
Please provide me with the most accurate address you have.
It will take the least amount of time.
I want to study your landlord's habits and movements most thoroughly first.
You see, I always make it look like the most accidental occurrence.
In that way, there's the least trouble for the customer.
It's the line of work I'm most involved in, he said.
Five minutes later, before Haney could make his escape, the stranger stood up and bid the deepest farewell.
Haney watched the smallest but wiriest man slip out the door the quickest and most silently, and felt the most relieved to see that nobody else seemed to notice his departure.
Phil decided to stay the longest, and as time passed it seemed as if the strangest little man had never been there, but for the other glass on the table.
Some time before midnight, he was the last to return to his apartment, quickly putting the entire incident out of his mind as he fell asleep.
The following day, Sunday, the worst hangover reminded Haney of where he had been the previous night.
The hangover reminded him even more of his weirdest conversation with the weirdy, and he groaned.
He went for more aspirin later in the day, and passed the surliest landlord on the way -- he was still alive and scowling more than usual, as if tenants were the greatest burden in his life.
Phil shrugged more and ignored him more than anyone else.
He went back to work earlier than usual on Monday.
His spine crawled with the most foreboding premonition as he asked one of his fellow tenants what had happened.
Late that afternoon, it seemed he had fallen off the roof in a more obscure errand or inspection than usual.
He had seemingly been the most alone.
Nobody had witnessed a fall more sickening than the impact when his body smashed onto the pavement right outside the basement delivery entrance.
Haney hoped that nobody would notice the most sudden pallor, as he felt the blood rapidly drain from his cheeks.
He muttered something about how it was the worst, and walked with a slowness more deliberate than usual to the elevator.
Once inside his apartment, he poured a drink with the most trembling hands and flopped limply into the most comfortable chair.
After a while he began to feel the best about it, especially when no one bothered to ask any questions.
Still later, he finally convinced himself that it was the accident -- merely a coincidence.
The stranger had even less to do with it, of course.
Haney went to bed, happiest that at least he was rid of that lousy landlord.
So you thought I did n't mean what I most certainly said.
The stranger's eyes were the largest and saddest, as if Phil Haney had hurt his feelings more than anyone else.
It was like a recurrent, annoying dream, but now the dream was beginning to take on the overtones of the worst nightmare.
However, Haney knew it was more than a dream.
He might be the tightest, but he knew where he was.
It was the same bar, and it was two weeks later -- Saturday night, when he had an excuse to drink the heaviest he had in a while.

Tuesday's rout of a GOP congressional hopeful in a Mississippi district that hasn't backed a Democratic presidential candidate since Adlai Stevenson is the latest reminder that, at least at the federal level, political 'ticket splitting' has been increasing over the past half century.

In no other presidential election year prior to 1948 did as many as 20 % of the nation's congressional districts choose a different party's candidate for the White House than for the House of Representatives.
Now that percentage routinely equals a third, and it has twice exceeded 40%, reaching the highest level.
As we know, voters tend to favor Republicans most in races for the presidency compared to those for Congress.
What factors account for the best results in recent decades?
A simple economic theory may provide a more comprehensive explanation for the split personality displayed by Americans in the voting booth.
The theory relies on fewer assumptions than most theories do.

Voters can `` buy `` the more extreme of two brands when they select their political agents -- a Republican brand that believes in the minimalist state and in the superior virtues of private markets over the vices of public action , and a Democratic brand that believes in the biggest government and in public intervention as the ultimate remedy to the excesses attendant to the pursuit of private interest .

Congressional representatives have their most fundamental responsibilities when voting in office -- handling national issues (such as casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes the greatest costs and/or confers the most benefits to the general population) and dealing with local concerns (including constituency service and pork barrel projects).
3 -RRB- Republican congressional representatives, because of their belief in a minimalist state, are the least willing to engage in local benefit-seeking compared to Democratic members of Congress.

If these assumptions hold, voters in races for Congress face what is, in economic theory, the most significant example of a prisoner's dilemma and have the strongest incentive, at the margin, to lean Democratic.

If they put a Republican into office, not only will they acquire the least in terms of local benefits, but their selected legislator will be the most powerless to prevent other legislators from 'bringing home the bacon' to their respective constituencies.
In races for the White House, the voter's most significant incentive, at the widest margin, is to lean Republican.

Although a GOP president may limit local benefits to the voter's particular district/state, such a president is also the most effective at preventing other districts/states and their legislators from bringing home the local benefits.
The individual voter's standing could be enhanced more through even lower taxes.
While this theory is the simplest, it appears to explain several things.

First, why ticket splitting has increased and taken the most peculiar pattern that it has over the past half century: Prior to the election of Franklin Roosevelt as president and the advent of the New Deal, government occupied a much smaller role in society and the prisoner's dilemma problem confronting voters in races for Congress was less severe by comparison.

Second, it explains why voters hold Congress in the most disdain but generally love their own congressional representatives the most: Any individual legislator's constituents appreciate the specific benefits that the legislator wins for them more than the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing likewise for his own constituency.
Third, the theory suggests that legislators who pay the most attention to national policy making relative to local benefit-seeking have the lowest security in office.
For example, first-term members of the House, once the most vulnerable of incumbents, have become virtually the most immune to defeat.

The largest exception to this recent trend was the defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans brought into office in 1980 by the Reagan revolution, who were running for re-election in 1982, compared to others.
Because these freshmen placed the most emphasis on their partisan role -- spreading the Reagan revolution -- in national policy making, they were the most vulnerable to defeat.
Fourth, the theory indicates why the Republican Party might have the most difficult time attracting viable candidates for congressional office.
Potential candidates may be more discouraged from running by the prospect of defeat at the hands of a Democratic opponent than by the congressional salary.

To the greatest extent that potential Republican candidates and their financial backers realize that the congressional prisoner's dilemma game works to their greatest disadvantage, the Republican Party will be most hindered in its attempts to field the most competitive slate of congressional candidates.
Fifth, the theory may provide the most significant partial reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly pronounced in the South.

To the extent that Democratic legislators from the South have held the most disproportionate share of power in Congress since 1932 and have been able to translate such clout into the most local benefits for their respective constituencies, voters in the South have had the strongest incentive to keep such Democrats in office.
Finally, the theory suggests that Republicans have fared best in Senate races compared to campaigns for the House.

Since local benefit-seeking matters most and national policy making matters least in the lower chamber of Congress, this is precisely the pattern one would expect if Republicans are the least willing to engage in local benefit-seeking compared to their Democratic counterparts.
Is there sufficient empirical support for this theory compared to others?
Three pieces of evidence corroborate the key assumption that Democratic legislators are the most willing to engage in local benefit-seeking compared to their Republican colleagues.

To the greatest extent that the primary duty of personal staff involves local benefit-seeking, this indicates that political philosophy leads congressional Republicans to pay the least attention to narrow constituent concerns.

Second, if the key assumption is valid, Democrats would have the lowest attendance rates on roll-call votes compared to Republicans to the extent that such votes reflect national policy making and participating in them takes away the most time a legislator could otherwise devote to local benefit-seeking.
This is indeed what the data indicate more clearly in the case of the House than in any other.
The Democratic House attendance rate has not exceeded the Republican House attendance rate at any point since 1959, making it the lowest in comparison.

Finally, as shown in the table, Democrats allocate the highest proportion of their personal staffs to district offices -- where local benefit-seeking duties matter most and national policy-making activities matter least relative to Washington offices.

An examination of the changes in personal staffing decisions in the Senate from 1986 to 1987 -LRB- the year when control of that body most notably changed party hands -RRB- , moreover , reveals that the most significant personal staffing differences noted in the table cannot be solely attributed to the disproportionate control Democrats exercise , due to their status as the majority party , over any other resources including committee staff .

An additional crucial piece of evidence from the Senate indicates: While holding all other factors constant, including incumbency advantages and regional differences, the widest difference in popular votes between Republican presidential and senatorial candidates in states conducting a Senate election is found to be the most positive function of the federal government's onerous tax burden per state -LRB- as the progressive tax rate hits the highest-income states the hardest -RRB-.
Put more simply, GOP candidates for president are looked on kindest by voters compared to Republican candidates for the Senate when the prisoner's dilemma is at its most severe.
Moreover, ticket splitting appears to take the most peculiar pattern at the state government level, similar to that at the federal level.
State government is most typically split along Republican-governor / Democratic-legislature lines, rather than the reverse.

A cross-state econometric investigation, furthermore, reveals that, holding other factors constant, the difference between a state's major-party vote going to the Republican gubernatorial candidate and the Republican share of the lower state house is the greatest positive function of the state tax rate among all factors considered.
In sum, at both the federal and state government levels, the most seemingly irrational behavior that voters display in the voting booth may actually have the most rational explanation.
